conclusion: Use given information and principles of equilibrium for forces to solve for coefficient of friction and angle.
Identify forces: mass = 15 kg, gravitational acceleration = 10 m/s², gravitational force = 150 N, pulling force = 90 N, frictional force = μN.
Resolve forces into horizontal and vertical components: F cos θ and F sin θ.
Establish equilibrium conditions: horizontal pulling force equals frictional force, vertical normal force plus vertical pulling force equals weight.
Express normal force: N = 150 - 90 sin θ.
Substitute N into horizontal equilibrium equation: 90 cos θ = μ (150 - 90 sin θ).
Solve for μ: μ = 90 cos θ / (150 - 90 sin θ).
Minimum force occurs when derivative of force with respect to θ is zero, use trigonometric identities and trial values.
Test θ = 37°: sin 37° = 0.6, cos 37° = 0.8, calculate N and μ.
Final answers: coefficient of friction μ = 0.75, angle θ = 37°.
